While previous syllabries were of the form 6*10=60 or 5*12+x this schema is 5*16=120+x at its core  
Where x denotes a devine extra row of vowels. See [Elamite](Elamite.html) and [Linear-B](Linear-B.html).

# Luwian hieroglyphs "luwili" â‰  LINEAR-A
Anatolian hieroglyphs are an indigenous logographic script native to central Anatolia, consisting of some 500 signs. They were once commonly known as Hittite hieroglyphs, but the language they encode proved to be Luwian, not Hittite. They are typologically similar to Egyptian hieroglyphs, but they are not known to have played the sacred role of hieroglyphs in Egypt. There is no demonstrable connection to Hittite cuneiform.  

# bilingual Hittite-Luwian environment
Earliest development within a bilingual Hittite-Luwian environment. For example, the sign which has the form of a "taking" or "grasping" hand has the value /ta/, which is precisely the Hittite word ta-/da- "to take," in contrast with the Luwian cognate of the same meaning which is la-.  

The first inscriptions confirmed as Luwian date to the Late Bronze Age, ca. 14th to 13th centuries BC.  

After some two centuries of sparse material, the hieroglyphs resume in the Early Iron Age, ca. 10th to 8th centuries BC. In the early 7th century BC, the Luwian hieroglyphic script, by then aged some 700 years, was marginalized by competing alphabetic scripts and fell into oblivion.  

Distribution centered around NeÅ¡a/Kanesh-Purushanda/Tarsos with whole Anatolia prolly as perifery  

NeÅ¡a gave rise to neÅ¡ili aka Hittite.

# cuneiform https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luwian_language#Cuneiform_Luwian

Compared to cuneiform Hittite, logograms are rare. Instead, most writing is done with the syllabic characters. A striking feature is the consistent use of 'full-writing' to indicate long vowels, even at the beginning of words. In this system a long vowel is indicated by writing it twice. For example, Ä«di "he goes" is written i-i-ti rather than i-ti, and Ända "in" is written a-an-ta rather than an-ta.

ğ‹‚  CARIAN LETTER ST CÎ¶  
ğ‹ƒ  CARIAN LETTER STâ‚‚ CÎ¶ â‡” K@Hindu  

The characters that are transliterated as -h- and -hh- have often been interpreted as pharyngeal fricatives [Ä§] and [Ê•]. However, they may have instead been uvular [Ï‡] and [Ê] or velar fricatives [x] and [É£]. In loans to Ugaritic, these sounds are transcribed with <á¸«> and <Ä¡>, while in Egyptian they are transcribed with ğ“ á¸« and ğ“¼ g.[28] As both of these languages had pharyngeal consonants, the Luwian sounds are unlikely to have been pharyngeal.  

A noteworthy phonological development in Luwian is rhotacism; in some cases, d, l, and n becomes r. For example, *Ä«di ('he gets') becomes Ä«ri and wala- '(die') becomes wara-.

ğ”–£ (U+145A3): This sign represents a quote marker in the Anatolian Hieroglyphs script. It is often used to indicate quoted speech or text.  

ğ”“ (U+143DD): This sign represents a name marker in the Anatolian Hieroglyphs script. It is used to mark names or titles of individuals.
